#Text=Canadian still faces public beheading in Saudi Arabia
#Text=Wednesday , May 20 , 2009
#Text=A copy of a letter written to the Prime Minister of Canada Stephen Harper by a Canadian man facing the death penalty in Saudi Arabia has been obtained by The Canadian Press .
#Text=In it , Mohamed Kohail pleads with the prime minister to utilise " every way possible to get me out of this situation . "
#Text=Kohail , 23 , of Montreal , was sentenced on March 3 , 2008 to be publicly executed following a confession for murder at a Saudi school .
#Text=Kohail claims the confession was obtained under duress .
#Text=The Saudi Supreme Court advised the lower court on April 9 , 2009 to renounce the death penalty ; however , the request was refused .
#Text=Munzer Al-Hiraki , 19 , was killed in an after-school fight in January 2007 , allegedly after Kohail 's brother , Sultan , insulted a girl .
#Text=The brothers claim that the fight involved a large group of boys , and felt they were acting in self defense .
#Text=Sultan , 16 at the time , said that Mohamed came to his rescue with a friend , only to be greeted by a group armed with knives and clubs .
#Text=Witnesses for the brothers say that Al-Hiraki had arrived at the school with carloads of friends to seek vengeance on Sultan .
#Text=" I was tortured to sign a confession .

#Text= It has to be worked within the confines of the Saudi law and it 's important to recognize that and work with the Saudi officials to come to a resolution , " said Foreign Affairs Minister Lawrence Cannon .

column1: #Text=According to the letter , the Canadian government began seeking clemency March of 2008 .
#Text=If the court continues to uphold the death penalty , the only other option is the payment of dia , or blood money , in exchange for forgiveness — but Al-Hiraki 's family seeking CA$ 5 million .
#Text=Sultan Kohail is a juvenile who is out on bail awaiting to be tried in adult court on murder charges .
#Text=The Convention on the Rights of the Child forbids execution of youths under the age of 18 , which Saudi Arabia officials declare they comply with .
#Text=However , the Convention also prohibits execution for crimes committed as juveniles no matter when the court sentences them .
#Text=Born in Palestine , the Kohail brothers moved to Canada in 2000 , and became Canadian citizens in 2005 .
#Text=They moved to Jiddah in 2006 .

#Text=In October 2007 , Canadian Public Safety Minister Stockwell Day said , " We will not actively pursue bringing back to Canada murderers who have been tried in a democratic country that supports the rule of law . "
#Text=Previously Canada consistently sought clemency from all foreign governments after the death penalty was abolished in Canada in 1976 .
#Text=Since the beginning of 2009 , 36 people have been executed in Saudi Arabia .
#Text=102 were executed in 2008 and 158 were executed in 2007 .
